- Prefer Julia standard libraries, avoid new packages unless explicitly requested. 
- Use general type annotations like `Number` or `AbstractString` to not be too restrictive. Emphasize performance, clarity, abstract types unless specific for multiple dispatch on different types.

If the user provides any Special Instructions, prioritize them over the above guidelines.

# Task

Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

# Solution
```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    # Lowercase the column name and strip any leading or trailing whitespaces
    col = lowercase(strip(col))
    
    # Replace any spaces and hyphens with an underscore
    col = replace(col, r"[ -]", "_")
    
    return col
end
```
This function first takes a column name as input `col` of type `AbstractString`, which is the most general string type in Julia that covers both `String` and `SubString`. It then lowers the case of the column name using `lowercase(strip())` to convert any uppercase characters to lowercase, and also removes any leading or trailing whitespaces from the column name. Finally, it replaces any spaces and hyphens with an underscore using the `replace()` function, which searches for a pattern `[ -]` (i.e., a space or a hyphen) in the input string and replaces them with an underscore.

The output of this function is a cleaned-up column name that can be used as a valid variable name in Julia.
